titleInfo.title: Post-Disaster Recovery in Adjuntas, Puerto Rico
titleInfo.subTitle: Exploring the Roles of Social Capital Activation, NGO Participation and Institutional Transformation

name.namePart: College of Social Sciences and Public Policy
Department of Urban and Regional Planning

mods:mods.abstract: This dissertation examines the interaction of social capital, interorganizational dynamics, the role of the third sector, and institutional change in post-disaster recovery context. The dissertation is a qualitative case study in the rural town of Adjuntas, Puerto Rico post-2017 Hurricane Maria. Puerto Rico was impacted by category 4 Hurricane Maria on September 20, 2017, and left a death toll around 3,000 to 4,000 people across the island and communities without communications systems, water, gasoline, road access and electric power for months and even over a year in some isolated communities. Around 6% of residents emigrated to US in the months right after the hurricane. The rural town of Adjuntas was selected to study disaster recovery within Puerto Rico due to its rural low-income context and its history of community participation in mining opposition and sustainable projects, with the local NGO Casa Pueblo playing a significant role in its history of community grassroot movements since 1980. This dissertation takes a three-paper approach. The first paper, in chapter two, is based on the social capital and post-disaster recovery literature. It uses the three dimensions of social capital, bonding, bridging, and linking to categorize and examine social capital dynamics. It concludes that disaster recovery is rooted in a game of relationships, with bonding social capital at the center of those relationships. In this paper, the central argument is that bonding social capital is used by communities as a gateway to other manifestations of social capital, such as bridging and linking. The second paper, in chapter three, discusses the role of non-governmental organizations in disaster recovery. This chapter confirms the literature about the key role of NGOs in post-disaster recovery, which often become first responders. It further claims that countries and communities where governmental response capacity is weak, post-disaster response is highly dependent on the response capacity of NGOs. This chapter also uses the metaphor of "sancochos comunitarios" to illustrate the interorganizational dynamics of NGOs discovered in Adjuntas. The third paper, in chapter four, suggests that a large-scale disaster presents an opportunity to shape institutional fields. They create the conditions to invite the integration of new players, including individuals, organizations, and networks that together have the potential to change institutional fields by creating new institutions, norms, collective consensuses and values that define the new society post-disaster recovery. This chapter integrates the concepts of sense of urgency, time compression, and institutional fields to develop an analytical framework as a tool to understand institutional change dynamics in post-disaster contexts.
